required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study of Safety and Efficacy of CNTO 148 in Patients With Severe Persistent Asthma
clinical_study.official_title: A Phase 2, Multicenter, Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Parallel-group, Dose-ranging Study Evaluating the Efficacy and Safety of CNTO 148 Administered Subcutaneously in Symptomatic Subjects With Severe Persistent Asthma

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of CNTO 148 (golimumab) in patients with severe persistent asthma.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a multicenter, randomized (the study medication is assigned by chance), double-blind (neither physician nor patient knows the treatment that the patient receives), placebo-controlled (an inactive substance that is compared with a drug to test whether the drug has a real effect in a clinical study), parallel-group (each group of patients will be treated at the same time), dose-ranging study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of CNTO 148. The study will consists of run-in phase (2 weeks), treatment period (52 weeks) and follow up period (24 weeks). The patients inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) medication will be standardized in the run-in phase and the treatment period contains first 24 weeks of treatment, the patients are required to remain on stable doses of concomitant corticosteroids (CS) medication (steroid stable phase). The steroid stable phase is followed by a 28-week steroid taper phase, during which a reduction of concomitant CS medication will be attempted. After completion of the study treatment, patients are to be followed for an additional 24 weeks. Patients will receive subcutaneous injections of 75, 150, or 300 mg of CNTO 148 or placebo every 4 weeks for 52 weeks followed 50,100, or 200 mg every 4 weeks through week 52. The safety of the patient will be monitored throughout the study.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Prebronchodilator Clinic-Measured, Percent-Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second
primary_outcome.description: The endpoint is change from baseline in prebronchodilator clinic-measured percent predicted Percent-Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second (FEV1) with Last Observation Carried Forward (LOCF) at 6 months. The baseline visit starts at the end of 2 weeks run in phase.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Severe Asthma Exacerbations Per Patient From Baseline Through 6 Months
primary_outcome.description: The endpoint is the average number of severe asthma exacerbations per patient from baseline through 6 months.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Asthma Quality of Life Questionnaire Score at 6 Months; Randomized Patients
secondary_outcome.description: The endpoint is the change from baseline in the overall Asthma Quality of Life Questionnaire (AQLQ) score at 6 months. The AQLQ is a validated and self-administered questionnaire to evaluate symptoms and Quality of Life (QOL) in subjects with asthma and it has 32 questions in 4 domains (symptoms, activity limitations, emotional function, and environmental stimuli). Participants were asked to score the importance of each of the positively identified problems on a 7-point scale (7 = not impaired at all - 1 = severely impaired).

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Rescue Medication Use at 6 Months; Randomized Patients
secondary_outcome.description: The endpoint is change from baseline in rescue medication use at Wk 24 where the rescue medication use was based on the average over 7 days prior to visit.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Severe Asthma Exacerbations Per Patient From Week 24 Through Week 52; Randomized Patients Who Did Not Discontinue Study Participation Prior to Week 24
secondary_outcome.description: The endpoint is the average number of severe asthma exacerbations per patient from Week (Wk) 24 through Wk 52 for the patients who did not discontinue study participation prior to Wk 24

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Oral Corticosteroids Dose at Week 52; Randomized Patients Who Received Oral Corticosteroids at Baseline
secondary_outcome.description: The endpoint is the change from baseline at Week (Wk) 52 in oral corticosteroids (OCS) dose for the randomized patients who received OCS at baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Domiciliary Morning Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR) at 6 Months; Randomized Subjects
secondary_outcome.description: The endpoint is the change from baseline in domiciliary morning PEFR at Week 24. PEFR— Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR): A measure of the speed of exhalation. The data were collected in the eDiary which was issued to each participant at screening. PEFR was collected morning and evening each day of the study.

intervention.description: Type=exact type, unit=mg, number=50, 75, 100, 150, 200 and 300, form=injection, route=subcutaneous. Every 4 weeks partciapnts will receive injections in 4 parallel treatment arms
Type=exact type, unit=mg, form=injection, route=subcutaneous. Placebo will be given from from Week 0 through Week 52.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Physician diagnosis of asthma for greater than or equal to 3 years and a diagnosis of severe persistent asthma forgreater than or equal to 1 year prior to screening
- Continuous treatment with high dose Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) and long acting beta-agonist for at least 3 months prior to screening
- Have evidence of at least 1 of the following in the 5 years prior to screening or during screening, reversible airway obstruction greater than or equal to 12 percentage change in forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) postbronchodilator; Diurnal variation in peak expiratory flow rate (PEFR) greater than or equal to 30 percentage change) and airway hyperresponsiveness
- Estimated frequency of symptoms on more than one-third of days for at least 3 months prior to screening (eg, wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness, cough, nocturnal awakening) despite treatment with high dose ICS and long-acting β2-agonist (LABA), with or without continuous oral corticosteroids
- Score of greater than or equal to 2 points on the asthma control questionnaire at screening.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmoanry disease (COPD), cystic fibrosis, or other significant respiratory disorder
- Worsening of asthma symptoms that required treatment with an addition or increase in oral corticosteroids dose (steroid burst) in the 4-week period prior to the screening visit
- Life-threatening asthma attack requiring cardiopulmonary support (eg, intubation) in the 6-month period prior to screening
- Have ever used alkylating agents (eg, chlorambucil or cyclophosphamide)
- Concomitant diagnosis or any history of congestive heart failure (CHF), including medically controlled CHF.

participant_flow.recruitment_details: A total of 309 patients were randomized into 4 parallel treatment groups at 53 sites (134 patients at 27 sites in the US and 175 patients at 26 sites in Europe). The first patient was consented on 31 Aug 2004, and the last patient completed the study on 17 Jul 2007.

group.title: Group I: Placebo
group.description: Placebo subcutaneous (SC) injections every 4 weeks (Wks) from week (Wk) 0 to Wk 52

group.title: Group II: Golimumab 50 mg
group.description: Golimumab (CNTO148) 75 mg SC injection at Wk 0 followed by 50 mg SC injections every 4 Wks to Wk 52

group.title: Group III: Golimumab 100 mg
group.description: Golimumab 150 mg SC injection at Wk 0 followed by 100 mg SC injections every 4 Wks to Wk 52

group.title: Group IV: Golimumab 200 mg
group.description: Golimumab 300 mg SC injection at Wk 0 followed by 200 mg SC injections every 4 Wks to Wk 52

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Prebronchodilator Clinic-Measured, Percent-Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second
outcome.description: The endpoint is change from baseline in prebronchodilator clinic-measured percent predicted Percent-Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second (FEV1) with Last Observation Carried Forward (LOCF) at 6 months. The baseline visit starts at the end of 2 weeks run in phase.
outcome.population: The analysis of this endpoint uses intent-to-treat population. Missing data were imputed using Last Observation Carried Forward (LOCF).

group.title: Group I: Placebo
group.description: Placebo subcutaneous (SC) injections every 4 weeks (Wks) from week (Wk) 0 to Wk 52

group.title: Group II: Golimumab 50 mg
group.description: Golimumab (CNTO148) 75 milligram (mg) SC injection at Wk 0 followed by 50 mg SC injections every 4 Wks to Wk 52

group.title: Combined: Group III & IV
group.description: Combines Group III (golimumab 100 mg) and Group IV (golimumab 200 mg)

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Prebronchodilator Clinic-Measured, Percent-Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second
measure.description: The endpoint is change from baseline in prebronchodilator clinic-measured percent predicted Percent-Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 Second (FEV1) with Last Observation Carried Forward (LOCF) at 6 months. The baseline visit starts at the end of 2 weeks run in phase.
measure.population: The analysis of this endpoint uses intent-to-treat population. Missing data were imputed using Last Observation Carried Forward (LOCF).

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis was that the endpoint for placebo is the same as that for combined 100 mg and 200 mg golimumab. Assuming a standard deviation of 23%, there is 86% power to detect a 10% difference at a 0.05 significance level.
analysis.p_value_desc: When interpreting this p-value along with the other co-primary endpoint, Hochberg procedure was used.
The nominal p-value is for descriptive purpose only.
The nominal p-value is for descriptive purpose only.
The nominal p-value is for descriptive purpose only.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Asthma Quality of Life Questionnaire Score at 6 Months; Randomized Patients
outcome.description: The endpoint is the change from baseline in the overall Asthma Quality of Life Questionnaire (AQLQ) score at 6 months. The AQLQ is a validated and self-administered questionnaire to evaluate symptoms and Quality of Life (QOL) in subjects with asthma and it has 32 questions in 4 domains (symptoms, activity limitations, emotional function, and environmental stimuli). Participants were asked to score the importance of each of the positively identified problems on a 7-point scale (7 = not impaired at all - 1 = severely impaired).
outcome.population: The analysis of this endpoint uses intent-to-treat population. Missing data were imputed using last observation carried forward.

measure.title: Change From Baseline in Asthma Quality of Life Questionnaire Score at 6 Months; Randomized Patients
measure.description: The endpoint is the change from baseline in the overall Asthma Quality of Life Questionnaire (AQLQ) score at 6 months. The AQLQ is a validated and self-administered questionnaire to evaluate symptoms and Quality of Life (QOL) in subjects with asthma and it has 32 questions in 4 domains (symptoms, activity limitations, emotional function, and environmental stimuli). Participants were asked to score the importance of each of the positively identified problems on a 7-point scale (7 = not impaired at all - 1 = severely impaired).
measure.population: The analysis of this endpoint uses intent-to-treat population. Missing data were imputed using last observation carried forward.

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis was that the endpoint for placebo is the same as that in the combined 100 mg and 200 mg golimumab.

outcome.title: Number of Severe Asthma Exacerbations Per Patient From Baseline Through 6 Months
outcome.description: The endpoint is the average number of severe asthma exacerbations per patient from baseline through 6 months.
outcome.population: The analysis of this endpoint uses intent-to-treat population. For the dropouts, the worst case in similar patients was used as the number of severe exacerbations.

group.title: Group I: Placebo
group.description: Placebo subcutaneous (SC) injections every 4 weeks (Wks) from week (Wk) 0 to Wk 52

group.title: Group II: Golimumab 50 mg

measure.title: Number of Severe Asthma Exacerbations Per Patient From Baseline Through 6 Months
measure.description: The endpoint is the average number of severe asthma exacerbations per patient from baseline through 6 months.
measure.population: The analysis of this endpoint uses intent-to-treat population. For the dropouts, the worst case in similar patients was used as the number of severe exacerbations.

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis was that the number of severe exacerbations per patient from baseline through week 24 for placebo is the same as that in the combined 100 mg and 200 mg golimumab. Assuming 1 severe exacerbation over 6 months per patient in the placebo group, there is 79% power to detect a 35% reduction in the combined 100 mg and 200 mg golimumab group at a 0.05 significance level.
analysis.p_value_desc: When interpreting this p-value along with the other co-primary endpoint, Hochberg procedure was used.
The nominal p-value is for descriptive purpose only.
The nominal p-value is for descriptive purpose only.
The nominal p-value is for descriptive purpose only.

outcome.population: The analysis of this endpoint uses intent-to-treat population. Missing data were imputed using last observation carried forward.

outcome.title: Number of Severe Asthma Exacerbations Per Patient From Week 24 Through Week 52; Randomized Patients Who Did Not Discontinue Study Participation Prior to Week 24
outcome.description: The endpoint is the average number of severe asthma exacerbations per patient from Week (Wk) 24 through Wk 52 for the patients who did not discontinue study participation prior to Wk 24
outcome.population: Analysis of this endpoint only includes patients (pts) who did not discontinue study participation prior to Wk 24. For the dropouts during the period between Wks 24- 52, worst case in similar pts was used as the number of severe exacerbations. Data from Wk 24-52 must be interpreted with caution as study agent was stopped at various study timepoints

measure.title: Number of Severe Asthma Exacerbations Per Patient From Week 24 Through Week 52; Randomized Patients Who Did Not Discontinue Study Participation Prior to Week 24

measure.population: Analysis of this endpoint only includes patients (pts) who did not discontinue study participation prior to Wk 24. For the dropouts during the period between Wks 24- 52, worst case in similar pts was used as the number of severe exacerbations. Data from Wk 24-52 must be interpreted with caution as study agent was stopped at various study timepoints
measure.units: Events per patient from Wk 24 thru Wk 52

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis was that the endpoint for placebo is the same as that in the combined 100 mg and 200 mg golimumab.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Oral Corticosteroids Dose at Week 52; Randomized Patients Who Received Oral Corticosteroids at Baseline
outcome.description: The endpoint is the change from baseline at Week (Wk) 52 in oral corticosteroids (OCS) dose for the randomized patients who received OCS at baseline.
outcome.population: Analysis of this endpoint includes only pts who received OCS at baseline.Wk 52 OCS dose is the daily OCS dose in the last period, defined as between 2 consecutive visits, in which no change in total daily dose of OCS occurred, prior to Wk 52 visit.Data from Wk 24-52 must be interpreted with caution as study agent was stopped at various timepoints.

measure.population: Analysis of this endpoint includes only pts who received OCS at baseline.Wk 52 OCS dose is the daily OCS dose in the last period, defined as between 2 consecutive visits, in which no change in total daily dose of OCS occurred, prior to Wk 52 visit.Data from Wk 24-52 must be interpreted with caution as study agent was stopped at various timepoints.

analysis.groups_desc: The null hypothesis was that the endpoint for placebo is the same as that in the combined 100 mg and 200 mg golimumab.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Domiciliary Morning Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR) at 6 Months; Randomized Subjects
outcome.description: The endpoint is the change from baseline in domiciliary morning PEFR at Week 24. PEFR— Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR): A measure of the speed of exhalation. The data were collected in the eDiary which was issued to each participant at screening. PEFR was collected morning and evening each day of the study.
outcome.population: The analysis of this endpoint uses intent-to-treat population. Missing data were imputed using last observation carried forward (LOCF).

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Generally, the only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor has 60 days to review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that does not exceed 180 days from the time submitted to the sponsor for review. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: The count of patients with any nonserious adverse events (NAE) excludes patients who only had NAE that occurred in <= 5% of patients. This information may vary from existing approved labeling and publications due to the requirement of this website.
